resources.string:
The networking / data access structure used in this sample app: 

Retrofit with RxJava for the REST API calls, and EventBus to deliver the results back to the presentation layer. 
Rx features to handle errors, multiple calls, fallback to offline store, and more. 
The whole component is placed in a Android Service which starts on-demand and stops when there are no more ongoing tasks. 

More info at each use-case.

User initiates data access, receives the result on UI. Requires a single network call. 
 
 - Displays loading indicator 
 - Handles rotation (keeps indicator, doesn't restart call) 
 - Can deliver result to different screen

Retrofit with RxJava for the API call, and EventBus to deliver the results back to the presentation layer. \nThe whole component is put in an Android Service which starts on-demand and stops when there is no more ongoing task.
Get the 5 day forecast for the city that is warmer currently

User initiates data access, receives the result on UI. 
Requires multiple network calls executed both parallel and chained (after previous one completed). 
 - Progress dialog displays steps in progress 
 - Handles rotation (keeps dialog, doesn't restart call)
Rx operator zip for parallel call, flatMap for chaining. \nProgress update events sent with EventBus at any point in Rx chain to presentation layer. \nRetained DialogFragment for the dialog.
No internet connection and no offline data

User initiates data access, receives the result on UI. Requires a single network call. 
 
 - Error message displayed if something went wrong 
 - Different messages for different errors
1. Use Real Weather Service (invalid API key used here -> error dialog) \n2. Disconnect from internet (no internet error message) \n3. Use Mock Weather service (completes successfully)
Errors propagate through the Rx chain and interpreted at single place at the end. Event sent to presentation layer where message is decided.
API key unauthorized. A custom message can come here..

Rx Subscription is kept in field and checked if subscribed.
Use Mock service (real one is too fast) and tap the button multiple times. Try basic use-case in comparison.
User initiates data access, receives the result on UI. \n - When online, network call is executed and result is displayed and saved \n - When offline, data is loaded from offline store (custom cache)
Rx operators doOnSuccess and onErrorResumeNext are used to construct the appropriate chain.
